item.title: Somehow This Robot Sticks to Ceilings by Vibrating a Flexible Disc - IEEE Spectrum
item.description: Just when I think I’ve seen every possible iteration of climbing robot, someone comes up with a new way of getting robots to stick to things. The latest technique comes from the Bioinspired Robotics and Design Lab at UCSD, where they’ve managed to get a robot to stick to smooth surfaces using a vibrating motor attached to a flexible disk. How the heck does it work?
item.author: (By Evan Ackerman)

item.title: The ARM processor (Thumb-2), part 5: Arithmetic | The Old New Thing
item.description: The general format of three-register instructions in Thumb-2 goes like this:¹ op Rd, Rn, #imm12 ; Rd = Rn op decode(imm12) op Rd, Rn, Rm ; Rd = Rn op Rm op Rd, Rn, Rm, shift ; Rd = Rn op (Rm with shift applied) ;
item.author: (Raymond Chen)

item.title: CDK for Terraform Adds Go Support and Improves Asset Construction
item.description: Hashicorp recently released version 0.4 of their CDK for Terraform. The CDK allows for writing Terraform configurations in a number of programming languages including C#, Python, TypeScripts, and Java. This release adds experimental support for using Go to write Terraform configurations. Also included are enhanced support for Terraform modules and asset construction.
item.author: (Matt Campbell)

item.title: Microsoft Announces Event Hubs Premium in Preview
item.description: Azure Event Hubs is Microsoft’s managed real-time event ingestion service designed to serve demanding big data streaming and event ingestion needs in the Cloud. Microsoft announced the public preview of Event Hubs Premium during the annual Build conference as a new product SKU tailor-made for high-end event streaming scenarios requiring elastic, superior performance with predictable latency.

item.title: The Anti-Bigness Ideology – Matt Bruenig Dot Com
item.description: Over at Slow Boring, Matt Yglesias has a piece arguing that Amazon is not a monopoly and that a lot of what passes for anti-monopoly discourse is actually anti-bigness discourse. I agree with Yglesias on this point. Not all anti-monopoly advocates are motivated by anti-bigness per se, but many of them are, and this can create some confusion when it comes to understanding what they are trying to achieve.

item.title: Distributed cloud builds for everyone
item.description: CPU cycles are cheaper than they have ever been, and cloud computing has never been more ubiquitous. All the major cloud providers offer generous free tiers, and services like GitHub Actions offer free compute resources to open-source repositories. So why do so many developers still build software on their laptops?
item.author: (Nelson Elhage)
